results.title: School for scoundrels
results.creator_credit: Robert Hamer, Hal E. Chester, ABP and Guardsman Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forever Ealing”.
Amusing British comedy about a constant “loser” (Ian Carmichael) who enrols in Alistair Sim’s School of Lifemanship” and there learns all the tricks to allow him to win the girl and get the better of two unscrupulous used car salesmen (Dennis Price and Peter Jones) as well as his rival in love and on the tennis court, Terry Thomas. Based on the book by Stephen Potter.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Hamer, Hal E. Chester, ABP and Guardsman Film Productions

results.title: The Lavender Hill Mob
results.creator_credit: Charles Crichton, Michael Truman and Ealing Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forever Ealing”.
This comedy stars Alec Guinness as an underpaid bank clerk who plans and executes a gold robbery but his colleagues’ attempt to hide the loot leads to bizarre and suspenseful complications. Also features Stanley Holloway and Sidney James. Won Academy award for Best story and screenplay.

results.title: Kind Hearts and Coronets
results.creator_credit: Robert Hamer, Sir Michael Balcon and Ealing Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forever Ealing”.
A genteel mass-murderer is out to heartlessly eliminate the eight relatives standing between him and the family fortune. Alec Guinness plays all eight victims in this witty black comedy. Based on the novel “Noblesse oblige” by Roy Horniman.

results.title: The Language of advertising (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Dibb and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Ways of seeing”.
One of a series of films by art critic and author, John Berger, which explores the ways in which we look at pictures. Shows how the images used in advertising and publicity are related to the tradition of oil painting, a connection which we fail to notice only because we are encouraged to believe that painting is fine art whereas publicity is simple commerce. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Possessions
results.creator_credit: Michael Dibb and TAFE National Video Resource Centre (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Ways of seeing”.
One of a series of films by art critic and author John Berger, which explores the ways in which we look at pictures. John Berger believes we have misunderstood the real meaning of European oil painting because we are normally encouraged to look at only a few exceptional works instead of the hundreds of thousands of unremakable pictures which make up the main tradition. He argues that this still continues today in the modern medium of advertising and publicity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Dibb and TAFE National Video Resource Centre (Australia)

results.title: Possessions (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Ways of seeing”.
One of a series of films by the distinguished art critic and author, John Berger, in which he explores the ways in which we look at pictures. Berger argues that paintings were, and still are, the most valuable single objects which we can possess.

results.title: Nude or naked?
results.creator_credit: Michael Dibb and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Ways of seeing”.
One of a series of films by art critic and author John Berger which explores the ways in which we look at pictures. He looks at oil paintings over the last 400 years of the nude and interprets painting as being made for a male audience. He asks whether there is a difference between being naked or nude. How do European oil paintings of nudes compare with the images of modern advertisements? Finally, he asks women for their comments on how men see them or have seen them in the past and on how this influences the way women see themselves. Attempts to explain the difference between nudity and nakedness in art. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.
